awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Petermann Gletscher, Greenland - Paleoceanography and Paleoclimatology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will take a multi-disciplinary approach to understanding the response of Petermann Glacier in northern Greenland to climate change in the past. Petermann Glacier drains a significant fraction of the northern Greenland ice sheet and terminates in a large floating ice shelf that is sensitive to ice-ocean interactions. Ice retreat over the last decade opens access to the fjord and presents an opportunity to understand sedimentation processes under the area previously covered by ice shelf and to calibrate reconstructions of past ice shelf variations. Using a variety of technologies and approaches on land, ice, and at sea, the investigators will map the bottom of the fjord in front of and under the ice shelf; reconstruct ocean conditions and their role in ice shelf variations through time; reconstruct the past extent of the glacier on land and the floating ice shelf; and reconstruct local relative sea level. Together these efforts will create a comprehensive picture of the climate conditions and response of the Petermann Glacier to these conditions over the last 10,000 years.

Of key interest will be the timing, extent, rates of change, and variability (on land and in the sea) during the early Holocene when local relative sea level was over 100 meters higher than today (due to lagging isostatic rebound of the crust in response to deglaciation), but the inland ice sheet was still large relative to today. The investigators will address dynamic responses to multiple interacting variables over a range of response times (from tens to thousands of years) relevant to potential future impacts. Specific research questions include: 1) How sensitive is Petermann ice shelf extent to documented climate changes within the Holocene? 2) Is shelf response independent of, or linked to, variations in the grounded Petermann Glacier, ocean thermal conditions, or relative sea level (i.e., sill depth)? 3) What are the rates of change and variability of these systems in response to early Holocene warming, Neoglacial cooling, and recent warming? The project will support several young investigators and will provide them with both ship and land-based training experiences. The project includes significant international collaborations, with substantial in-kind contributions from non-U.S. sources that add value to the project. Planned outreach includes teacher participation in the field program and meaningful classroom involvement at several levels.

por.por_cntn:
This study focused on the Petermann Glacier system, which drains a significant fraction of the northern Greenland Ice Sheet and terminates in a large floating ice tongue that is thought to be sensitive to ice-ocean interactions. Ice retreat over the last two decades has opened access to the fjord and presents a rare opportunity to understand sedimentation processes under the previous ice shelf and to calibrate paleo-reconstructions of past ice shelf variations, likely generally applicable to other systems. The Petermann system was selected for detailed study because it is large and important to the Greenland system, but of a size and location that is logistically manageable with an opportunity to measure and monitor, and eventually to model, many features relevant to ice ocean interaction over large scales. Outcomes from the Petermann Expedition aboard Icebreaker Oden are as follows: 

Intellectual Merit - Petermann Glacier advanced in late glacial time evidenced by emplacement of moraines dated near 10,000 years ago, following the Last Glacial Maximum and as Greenland was beginning to warm. This late advance likely reflects a transition of the ice bed from a frozen to melted state, evidenced by cosmic ray exposure in subglacial boulders.  During peak warmth in the early Holocene, evidenced by regional ice core data, as well as ocean temperature reconstructions from foraminiferal faunas, the Petermann floating ice tongue retreated rapidly, near 8000 years ago, resulting in the onset of ice-rafted debris in the fjord dropped by icebergs from a grounded calving front. A possible triggering event for ice tongue retreat may be marine ice cliff collapse (evidenced by bathymetric mapping of retreat moraines on the retrograde slope of the Petermann Sill) which followed an earlier more gradual loss of ice in the region (based on cosmogenic exposure dating). Much of the grounded ice mass was also lost at this time, evidenced by rapid isostatic uplift between about 9000 and 7000 BP – faster than implied by published isostatic adjustment models. Deposits on land dated by cosmogenic exposure reveal at least two Holocene advances relative to current ice margins (near 2500 BP, and again within the past millennium), associated with late Holocene cooling that culminating in a Little Ice Age advance. The current Petermann Ice Tongue is a relatively young (last millennium) feature, which is now beginning to retreat under the attack of anthropogenic warming in both the atmosphere and the ocean. A key finding is that within the next few decades, current and projected warming in the region will very likely exceed the level associated with early Holocene ice tongue collapse, and this implies that future ice tongue retreat may occur soon, yielding a system that sheds thicker, but smaller icebergs from the grounded ice front instead of larger shallower tabular bergs from the ice tongue. To the extent that the existing floating ice tongue provides some buttressing to the inland portions of the Petermann Glacier which remain below sea level, it is reasonable to hypothesize some acceleration of ice losses from Greenland through this pathway; future modeling studies of this issue will benefit from the observational constraints provided by the Petermann Glacier Experiment. 

Broader Impacts - The program included extensive outreach operations.  For the research community from other fields that might not be aware of this research or its publications, we hosted a special session of the American Geophysical Union which highlighted the Petermann Glacier project as exemplary for paleo-ice-ocean interactions and for understanding rates of ice loss. We participated in many research talks and posters at American Geophysical Union, Geological Society of American and The Oceanography Society-Ocean Sciences in the US, and for the European Geosciences Union and the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme - Past Global Changes open meetings in Europe, and in community workshops (NSF-GRISO for the larger Greenland research community, and PAGES/PALSEA for the sea-level community). Public-facing outreach including Social media included Twitter (@Petermann_ice), Instagram (@Peterman_ice), and a web blog (www.petermannsglacialhistory.wordpress.com ) as well award-winning videos (www.petermannsglacialhistory.wordpress.com/videos). In the field we hosted a CBS News 60 Minutes team for a television feature, which aired twice in 2016 and had a viewership of ~10 million people (more since posting online as open access). The study opened research opportunities for undergraduates from a variety of fields. The Petermann team participated in US House and Senate visits (climate science day), a Policy Forum for the Consortium for Ocean Leadership, and gave numerous public talks including video presentations that were well received by the non-scientific public audience. We held a teleconference with three US Senators (McCain, Whitehouse, Barrasso) and Swedish dignitaries in the Arctic Council and had regular communications with the governments of Nunavut, Canada, and Greenland. We hosted an indigenous people’s representative from Grise Fjord, Canada in Greenland. A post-cruise newsletter item for ARCUS highlighted US-Swedish research agreements for future collaboration.
